description:
After a vote and general assembly yesterday evening, the undergraduate student body has decided to vote YES on supporting the Student Strike for Palestine.

LINGUA affiliated students have agreed to hold an undergraduate, department-wide strike on
November 21st and 22nd. Students may stand outside classrooms or the Linguistics Building to inform other students of the strike happening. Students will be encouraged to participate in or organize demonstrations on campus in collaboration with the broader “Student Strike for Palestine” movement. Students are encouraged to make announcements of the strike on November 21st and 22nd in their respective linguistics classes. This will be a soft picket. No one will be blocked from attending academic activities.

Thus, we encourage all lingustics students to join in striking for a Free Palestine and to call on McGill to divest from Israeli investments, and the university’s investments in military and defense infrastructure.

This Friday’s talk: Karlos Arregi (University of Chicago): The relation between head movement and periphrasis.

“In joint work with Asia Pietraszko, I’ve been investigating the relation between head movement and the synthesis-periphrasis distinction in the verbal domain. We use the term “synthesis” to refer to verbal expressions in which the lexical verb bears all the verbal inflection in a clause (e.g. “rode” in English). In contrast, a periphrastic verbal expression additionally contains an auxiliary verb (specifically, “be” or “have”), and verbal inflection is distributed between the lexical verb and the auxiliary (e.g. “had ridden”). We argue for two crosslinguistic generalizations: AfTonomy and *V-Aux. According to AfTonomy, affixal Ts vary as to whether they are in a head movement relation with a verb. *V-Aux states that in periphrasis, the lexical verb and the auxiliary cannot be related by head movement. Existing analyses of periphrasis can account for one or the other generalization, but not for both. We further argue that this tension between the two generalizations is resolved if we adopt the hypothesis that both head movement and periphrasis are tied to selection. More specifically, we propose that head movement is parasitic on a selectional relation (following Svenonius 1994, Julien 2002, Matushansky 2006, and Preminger 2019) and that auxiliaries are merged as specifiers selected by functional heads such as T (Pietraszko 2017).”

As per usual, all are welcome! Come see what research professors at other universities are conducting—colloquiums are an excellent opportunity for students to learn about diverse topics and get a sense for linguistics academia.

LINGUA is hosting a general assembly on Tuesday, November 19th @ 7pm to vote anonymously on endorsing the “Student Strike for Palestine”, happening November 21st-22nd. 

We encourage every linguistics minor, major, honours student to come through and VOTE !

The general assembly will be hosted in the linguistics lounge. That’s in 1085 Dr Penfield Ave.

JournalLing, the McGill Linguistics undergraduate publications journal, is accepting submissions for the 2024/2025 school year! We are currently accepting papers from all linguistics fields, as well as related fields like cognitive science. Your paper can be from past semesters or be written for this semester, but our acceptances for papers will be rolling into the next semester as well. The Google Form for submission can be found in our bio. If possible, please submit the papers themselves anonymously (remove your name before submitting the PDF, but indicate your name on the Google Form). If you have any questions, please reach out to us at journallingmcgill@gmail.com.

🚨‼️due to the Student Strike for Palestine, EPP IS POSTPONED!🚨‼️
‼️🚨Tentative new date: Dec. 2nd !🚨‼️

Extended Projection Principle or Eating Pizza with Profs?

It’s our favorite time of the semester, EPP!!!! (previously known as profs & bizza) Come join us for some free pizza, free drinks and fun conversations with professors. 👨‍🏫👩‍🏫🍷🍕

LINGUA and MPSA are very excited to bring you this event together. Join us next Friday, Nov 15 to watch one of three excellent films that explore language, behaviour and the mind… and enjoy popcorn and the atmosphere of wonderful Peel St Cinema. Entry and popcorn are free! The seats will be first come first serve, so rsvp and vote for a movie at the link in the QR or @linguamcgill or @mpsa.mcgill ‘s linktree. See you there 🎥🍿🧠💬❤️
Merch sale ends TOMORROW end of day. Get your LINGUA tee, hoodie, sticker, or tote bag to help fund our activities and look fashionable while doing it. Link in story and linktree.

One of Jordan’s personal fav events of the year - TRIVIA NIGHT : Come hang with us and do some linguistics (without the stress of grades) with a LINGUA trivia night at Ye Olde Orchard on Monday, November 18th at 6:00pm!  Relax from your usual worries about null DPs and choose which one of these languages has an alveolar flap. (Thank u esme)

Next colloquium is this Friday! All are welcome! Come see what research professors at other universities are conducting—colloquiums are an excellent opportunity for students to learn about diverse topics and get a sense for linguistics academia. 

This Friday’s guest, Linnaea Stockall (Queen Mary University of London): The neural bases of linguistic structure building vs. Interpretation across the world’s languages

“In this talk, I’ll discuss a program of research that combines a very simple single word lexical decision paradigm with concurrent MEG recording to investigate how we assemble complex linguistics units (morphologically complex words and minimal phrases) from their consistent pieces, and how we generate and assess the interpretations that correspond to those structures. I’ll survey evidence my SAVANT team (https://savant.qmul.ac.uk/) and I have now collected from 7 languages (with 3 more in progress) that is consistent with a successive cyclic Y model of grammar, in which initial syntactic composition precedes and feeds subsequent interpretation, and word internal processes rely on the same neural resources and mechanisms as sentential processes.”
